node.title: Expectations for Covid care ignore stretched workforce - NZMA
node.description: The Medical Association is warning all doctors that the impact of Covid-19 on general practice is at crisis point.
node.content:
["The Medical Association (NZMA) is warning all doctors that the impact of Covid-19 on general practice is at crisis point.", "", "
(File image) Photo: 123RF
", "The association has sent out what is called a 'red letter', which is only rarely used to communicate matters of importance to its members.", "It had serious concerns about government expectations of general practice over the management of Covid-19 in the community, NZMA said.", "Insufficient consideration had been given of the impact on frontline workers, it said.", "Significant and growing demands have come with little or no engagement or effort to agree on details or terms of the services implemented, it said.", "The association is concerned that expectations of general practice ignore matters of capacity, which is already stretched, matters of workforce, which is already stressed, matters of sustainability, which is already at crisis point and the health of other patients who may be impacted.", "NZMA said doctors should think about their already stressed out staff and the impact on other patients, before committing to caring for Covid-19 cases, over and above normal GP services.", "It is telling GPs that if they believe they do not have the capacity to safely offer this service, then they should inform their primary health organisation (PHO) and/or their district health board (DHB) in writing with their concerns and ask them to urgently consider alternative pathways.", "The letter reminds doctors that if they have been asked to provide Covid-19 community care for a particular patient referred to them or someone seeking help, doctors are ethically bound to provide care if it is an emergency situation.", "If not, doctors can decline care as long as an alternative source of care is available and the appropriate avenue for securing help is known to the patient.", "NZMA acknowledged access to alternative care may be limited, particularly in rural areas. It believed the Ministry of Health and DHBs should urgently establish alternative care pathways."]
